com.eightsines.holycycle

Interface ViewController

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    ViewControllerActivity, ViewControllerAppCompatActivity, ViewControllerFragment, ViewControllerFragmentActivity, ViewControllerPlatformFragment

    public interface ViewController
    A view controller is an object, which manages piece of an application's user interface. This is an abstraction over Activity or Fragment lifecycle, which makes it more straightforward and consistent.

    Most of time you should use ViewControllerActivity, ViewControllerFragmentActivity, ViewControllerAppCompatActivity, ViewControllerFragment, or ViewControllerPlatformFragment instead of using this interface directly.

    The new lifecycle is:

    1. onControllerCreate(Bundle extras)
    2. onControllerRestoreInstanceState(Bundle savedInstanceState) (optional)
    3. onControllerGetContentLayoutId()
    4. onControllerContentViewCreated()
    5. onControllerStart()
    6. onControllerResume()
    7. onControllerFocus()
    8. onControllerBlur()
    9. onControllerPause()
    10. onControllerPersistUserData()
    11. onControllerStop()
    12. onControllerSaveInstanceState(Bundle outState) (optional)

    Every lifecycle method is called exactly in this order.

      Called after onControllerGetContentLayoutId() (and after onControllerContentViewCreated(), if onControllerGetContentLayoutId() has returned a non-zero layout id).
      void onControllerStop()
      Called when the view controller are no longer visible to the user.

    • Method Detail

      • onControllerCreate

        void onControllerCreate(@Nullable
                        android.os.Bundle extras)
        Called when the view controller is creating. This is where most initialization should go (you can think of this method as constructor replacement). Good place to inject dependencies.
        Parameters:
        extras - Intent extras (in case of Activity) or construction arguments (in case of Fragment).

      • onControllerRestoreInstanceState

        void onControllerRestoreInstanceState(@NonNull
                                      android.os.Bundle savedInstanceState)
        This method mey be called after onControllerCreate(Bundle extras) (but before onControllerStart()), when the view controller is being re-initialized from a previously saved state, given here in savedInstanceState.

        Controller UI is not yet created, so you must not use findViewById(int id) here or modify UI in any other way (eg. showing dialogs or working with fragments). It is better to save the necessary data in the class attributes.

        If the view controller is started without previously saved state, this method will not be called.

        Parameters:
        savedInstanceState - The data most recently supplied in onControllerSaveInstanceState(Bundle outState).

      • onControllerGetContentLayoutId

        int onControllerGetContentLayoutId()
        Called when the view controller wants to create UI. This is optional, and non-graphical view controllers can return zero (which is the default implementation). This will be called between onControllerCreate(Bundle extras) and onControllerStart().

        If this view controller based on Fragment, than in some cases this method can be called after onControllerStop().

        Returns:
        Return the layout id for the view controller UI, or zero for non-graphical view controller.

      • onControllerContentViewCreated

        void onControllerContentViewCreated()
        Called immediately after onControllerGetContentLayoutId() has returned a non-zero layout id (if onControllerGetContentLayoutId() has returned zero, this method will not be called). This gives subclasses a chance to initialize themselves once they know their view hierarchy has been completely created.

        Good place to use findViewById(int id) (if you don't already use kotlin extensions or data binding) and create adapters for ListView or RecyclerView.

        But you shouldn't register any View listeners (eg. click listeners) here - use onControllerStart() instead.

      • onControllerStart

        void onControllerStart()
        Called after onControllerGetContentLayoutId() (and after onControllerContentViewCreated(), if onControllerGetContentLayoutId() has returned a non-zero layout id). When this method is called, it means that the view controller is ready for operation (but not necessary active or even visible to user).

        Also can be called after onControllerStop(), if the view controller is restarted.

        Good place to register View listeners (eg. click listeners), subscribe to observables or event bus, register broadcast receivers, and reflect last application state into UI.

        NB. Internally this method is called directly from onStart() in Activity or Fragment, so due to nature of Android, calling this method does NOT mean that this view controller is shown to a user at first time (for example, Activity of Fragment can be destroyed and created again after screen rotation).

      • onControllerResume

        void onControllerResume()
        Called after onControllerStart() and mean that the view controller is ready to interact with user.

        Keep in mind that this method doesn't mean that this view controller is actually visible to user (a system window such as the keyguard may be in front). Use Activity.onWindowFocusChanged(boolean hasFocus) to know for certain that your view controller is visible to the user (for example, to resume a game).

        Also can be called after onControllerPause(), if the view controller is resuming after pause.

        Good place to begin animations and open exclusive-access devices (such as the camera).

      • onControllerFocus

        void onControllerFocus()
        Called after onControllerResume() when the view controller gains window focus. This means that this view controller is active, visible to the user and not covered by any other window.

        In most cases, you do not need to override this method.

      • onControllerBlur

        void onControllerBlur()
        Called after onControllerFocus() when the view controller lost window focus. This means that this view controller is still active, but not visible (or partially visible) to the user.

        In most cases, you do not need to override this method.

      • onControllerPause

        void onControllerPause()
        Called when the view controller is going into the background (but has not (yet) been stopped and killed). The counterpart to onControllerResume().

        Good place to stop animations and releasing exclusive-access devices (such as the camera).

      • onControllerPersistUserData

        void onControllerPersistUserData()
        Called immediately after onControllerPause(). This is last change to persist important user data, because after this method an application may be killed by Android without calling onStop and onDestroy in Activities and Fragments (in terms of view controller - without calling onControllerStop() and onControllerSaveInstanceState(Bundle outState)).

      • onControllerStop

        void onControllerStop()
        Called when the view controller are no longer visible to the user. You will next receive either onControllerStart() (or onControllerGetContentLayoutId() in case of Fragment), onControllerSaveInstanceState(Bundle outState) or nothing, depending on later user activity.

        Good place to unregister View listeners (eg. click listeners), unsubscribe from observables or event bus, and unregister broadcast receivers.

        Why you need to unregister listeners? See https://stackoverflow.com/q/38368391. Question answer suggests to disable button, but than you should re-enable it in onControllerStart(), because the view controller can be restarted. Unregistering listeners seems more straightforward and consistent.

      • onControllerSaveInstanceState

        void onControllerSaveInstanceState(@NonNull
                                   android.os.Bundle outState)
        This method may be called after onControllerStop() to retrieve per-instance state from this view controller. For more details see documentation for Activity.onSaveInstanceState(Bundle outState).

        onSaveInstanceState() in Activity or Fragment is not related to lifecycle, and can be called at any time before onStop(), even before onPause() (or after onStop() in Android P). In contrast, this method is always called after onControllerPause() and onControllerStop().

        Parameters:
        outState - Bundle in which to place your saved state.

      • getView

        @Nullable
android.view.View getView()
        Returns the content view of this view controller, if non-zero layout id was returned from onControllerGetContentLayoutId(), otherwise returns null.
        Returns:
        The content view or null.

      • findViewById

        @Nullable
<T extends android.view.View> T findViewById(@IdRes
                                                       int id)
        Finds a view that was identified by the android:id XML attribute.
        Parameters:
        id - The ID to search for.
        Returns:
        A view with given ID if found, or null otherwise.
